sen.j: 騎馬隊（cavalry）（きばたい）とは、兵士が馬にまたがり刀剣や槍、銃などで武装した兵士たちを集めて戦闘団にしたもの。
sen.e: Cavalry was a military force formed by soldiers mounting on horseback, armed with swords, spears, and guns.
Cavalry was a military force formed by soldiers mounting on horseback, armed with swords, spears, and guns.
Cavalry was a military force formed by soldiers mounting on horseback, armed with swords, spears, and guns.

sen.j: 歩兵と比較して高い機動力、衝力を誇る。
sen.e: A mounted soldier had the advantages of high speed and great impact over an opponent on foot.
Mounted soldiers had the advantages of high speed and great impact over their opponents on foot.
sen.cmt: a mounted soldier→Mounted soldiersan opponent →their opponents
sen.e: Mounted soldiers had the advantages of high speed and great impact over their opponents on foot.

sen.j: 中世当時、位の高い者達(侍・騎士)しかなれなかった。
sen.e: In the Medieval ｐeriod, only a person of high rank (samurai or knight) was able to join cavalry.
In the Medieval ｐeriod, only a person of high rank (samurai or knight) was able to join cavalry.
In the Medieval ｐeriod, only a person of high rank (samurai or knight) was able to join cavalry.

sen.j: 現在では、本来の役目ではなく式典の名物のひとつとなっていることが多い。
sen.e: Today, it almost lost its original function and became one of the features of ceremony.
Today, it almost lost its original function and became one of the features of ceremony.
Today, it almost lost its original function and became one of the features of ceremony.

sen.j: 現在でも警察の騎馬隊が町をパトロールする姿は少なくない。
sen.e: A police cavalry often patrols the city even now.
The police cavalry often patrol the city even now.
sen.cmt: a police cavalry often patrols → The police cavalry often patrol
sen.e: The police cavalry often patrol the city even now.

sen.j: (ｲｷﾞﾘｽなど)
sen.e: (In England)
(In England and other countries)
(In England and other countries)

sen.j: 歴史
sen.e: History
History
History

sen.j: 日本の騎馬隊は古代日本の軍制が律令制に基づく軍団 (古代日本)から国衙軍制へ転換して以降、軍事力の中心となった騎馬武者とその供(時代により従卒、武家奉公人と言われる)を基本単位として構成された部隊を指していた。
sen.e: After army corps in the ancient Japanese military system based on the Ritsuryo codes changed into the Kokuga forces system (provincial forces system), cavalry was referred to as troops fundamentally composed of mounted warriors as a major military force and their attendants (they were called differently as Jusotsu [an officer's servant] or Buke hokonin [a servant for a samurai family] depending on the times).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: After the ancient Japanese military system based on the Ritsuryo codes changed into the Kokuga forces system (provincial forces system), Japanese cavalry had been referred to troops composed of units of mounted warriors, which was a major military force, and their attendants (they were called differently as Jusotsu [an officer's servant] or Buke hokonin [a servant for a samurai family] depending on the times).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処はOK原文の沿って修正しました。
sen.e: After the ancient Japanese military system based on the Ritsuryo codes was replaced with the Kokuga forces system (provincial forces system), the term "Japanese cavalry" was used to refer to troops composed of units of mounted warriors, which amounted to a major military force, and their attendants (known as Jusotsu [officer's servants] or Buke hokonin [servants to samurai families] depending on the times).

sen.j: 足軽が戦闘要員として台頭するまでは基本的に公儀の戦闘は武士団騎馬隊のみが行うものと認識されていた。
sen.e: Until the emergence of Ashigaru (foot soldiers) as combat personnel, it was generally accepted that official battles were basically conducted only by cavalry of samurai groups.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Until the emergence of ashigaru (foot soldiers) as combat personnel, it was generally accepted that official battles were basically conducted only by cavalry of samurai groups.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処はOKAshigaru → ashigaru
sen.e: Until the emergence of ashigaru (foot soldiers) as combat personnel, it was generally accepted that official battles were basically conducted only by cavalry of samurai groups.

sen.j: 戦国時代 (日本)以降、足軽が新たな戦闘力として認識されると、戦国大名の軍制は備を基本としたものへ変貌した。
sen.e: After the Sengoku period (Japan), when Ashigaru began to be recognized as a new fighting force, the military system of Sengoku daimyo (Japanese territorial lord in the Sengoku peiord) shifted to that in which defenses were strengthened.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: After the Sengoku period (Japan), when ashigaru began to be recognized as a new fighting force, the military system of Sengoku daimyo (Japanese territorial lord in the Sengoku peiord) shifted to that in which defense was regarded as a fundamental.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処はOKAshigaru → ashigarudenfeses were strengthened →defense was regarded as a fundamental.
sen.e: After the Sengoku period (Japan), when ashigaru began to be recognized as a new fighting force, the military system of Sengoku daimyo (Japanese territorial lord in the Sengoku peiord) shifted to that in which defense was regarded as a fundamental.

sen.j: その中で騎馬隊は備の一隊として足軽隊の形成した前線の突破、又はそれらに対する逆襲が主な任務とされた。
sen.e: Under such circumustances, the main duties of cavalry as defence forces were a breakthrough on the front-line troops of Ashigaru and a counterattack against them.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Under such circumustances, the main duty of cavalry as defence forces was to break through the front-line of ashigaru troops or to make a counterattack against the opponent's ashigaru troop.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処はOK原文に沿って修正しましたが、「それらに対する逆襲」の意味がわかりにくいので a counterattack against the opponent's ashigaru troopと補足しました。
sen.e: Under these circumstances, the main duty of the cavalry as a defense force was to break through the front-line of ashigaru troops or to launch counterattacks against the opponent's ashigaru troops.

sen.j: 一備に配備される騎馬隊は二十～五十騎で編成されており、騎馬隊々士の知行は二百石から三百石程度である。
sen.e: Cavalry deployed for a defence force unit was composed of twenty to fifty horsemen; each horseman received an annual stipend of about 200 to 300 koku.
Cavalry deployed for a defence force unit was composed of twenty to fifty horsemen; each horseman received an annual stipend of about 200 to 300 koku.
Cavalry deployed for a defence force unit was composed of twenty to fifty horsemen; each horseman received an annual stipend of about 200 to 300 koku.

sen.j: 彼ら侍の軍役は自弁が原則である為、引き連れてゆく供(武家奉公人)は自身の援護に付く若党(1騎に対し1~2人)を除けば、槍持や小荷駄といった後方要員がその殆どを占めていた。
sen.e: In principle, each samurai paid his own expenses during the military service; his attendants (Buke hokonin) accompanying him were mostly rearguard supporters such as spear carriers or provision transporters except young samurai who served to protect him (one to two persons for each horseman).

In principle, each samurai paid his own expenses during the military service; his attendants (Buke hokonin) accompanying him were mostly rearguard supporters such as spear carriers or provision transporters except young samurai who served to protect him (one to two persons for each horseman).

In principle, each samurai paid his own expenses during the military service; his attendants (Buke hokonin) accompanying him were mostly rearguard supporters such as spear carriers or provision transporters except young samurai who served to protect him (one to two persons for each horseman).

sen.j: また、騎馬隊といえば、戦国期甲斐国の武田信玄の騎馬隊が有名であるが、これは古来から甲斐や信濃国に御牧が設置され騎馬の扱いに長けた者や馬の産地が多く甲斐の黒駒伝承に象徴されるイメージ的な要素や、かの地の馬が山岳機動に優れた能力を示したといった様々な説が唱えられている。
sen.e: Speaking of cavalry, the one that belonged to Shingen TAKEDA in the Kai Province during the Sengoku period was famous because of following reasons; the imperial pastures were established in the Kai and Shinano Provinces from ancient times, so there were many people who excelled in handling horses, and also many places for breeding horses; these areas had an image symbolized by the legend of a black horse of Kai; the horses bred in these areas showed high mobile ability in mountainous regions.

Speaking of cavalry, the one that belonged to Shingen TAKEDA in the Kai Province during the Sengoku period was famous because of following reasons; the imperial pastures were established in the Kai and Shinano Provinces from ancient times, so there were many people who excelled in handling horses, and also many places for breeding horses; these areas had an image symbolized by the legend of a black horse of Kai; the horses bred in these areas showed high mobile ability in mountainous regions.

Speaking of cavalry, the one that belonged to Shingen TAKEDA in the Kai Province during the Sengoku period was famous because of following reasons; the imperial pastures were established in the Kai and Shinano Provinces from ancient times, so there were many people who excelled in handling horses, and also many places for breeding horses; these areas had an image symbolized by the legend of a black horse of Kai; the horses bred in these areas showed high mobile ability in mountainous regions.

sen.j: 戦術
sen.e: Cavalry operations
Cavalry operations
Cavalry operations

sen.j: 騎馬武者の戦闘法は平安時代においては騎射が主流であったが、治承・寿永の乱の頃より馬ごと相手にぶつかり、馬上で相撲を行い、落馬させて首を取るという新たな戦闘スタイルが登場する。
sen.e: In the Heian period, shooting arrows on horseback was the main battle style of mounted warriors; after the Jisho-Juei Civil War, a new battle style appeared, in which a mounted warrior crushed into the enemy together with his horse, wrestled the enemy on horseback, killed the enemy by thowing him off from the horse.

In the Heian period, shooting arrows on horseback was the main battle style of mounted warriors; after the Jisho-Juei Civil War, a new battle style appeared, in which a mounted warrior crushed into the enemy together with his horse, wrestled the enemy on horseback, killed the enemy by thowing him off from the horse.

In the Heian period, shooting arrows on horseback was the main battle style of mounted warriors; after the Jisho-Juei Civil War, a new battle style appeared, in which a mounted warrior crushed into the enemy together with his horse, wrestled the enemy on horseback, killed the enemy by thowing him off from the horse.

sen.j: 鎌倉時代まではそれでも流鏑馬に代表される様に騎射が主流であったが、鎌倉時代後期から室町時代になると悪党・野伏などの出現によりこの傾向は更に加速され、騎馬武者の戦闘は斬撃武器である長巻や薙刀を用いる様になる。
sen.e: Even until the Kamakura period, shooting arrows on horseback as typified in Yabusame (horseback archery) was the main style; from the late Kamakura period to the Muromachi period, this trend was accelerated due to the emergence of villains and armed peasants, and the battle style of mounted warriors shifted to the use of cutting weapons such as a long sword or a Japanese halberd.

Even until the Kamakura period, shooting arrows on horseback as typified in Yabusame (horseback archery) was the main style; from the late Kamakura period to the Muromachi period, this trend was accelerated due to the emergence of villains and armed peasants, and the battle style of mounted warriors shifted to the use of cutting weapons such as a long sword or a Japanese halberd.

Even until the Kamakura period, shooting arrows on horseback as typified in Yabusame (horseback archery) was the main style; from the late Kamakura period to the Muromachi period, this trend was accelerated due to the emergence of villains and armed peasants, and the battle style of mounted warriors shifted to the use of cutting weapons such as a long sword or a Japanese halberd.

sen.j: 甲冑も大鎧から腹巻へと変わり、鞍の深さも浅いものへとなった。
sen.e: The style of a body-armor also shifted from Oyoroi (heavy armor) to Haramaki (a breast protection); a shallow saddle was more used than a deep one.
The style of a body-armor also shifted from Oyoroi (heavy armor) to Haramaki (a breast protection); a shallow saddle was more used than a deep one.
The style of a body-armor also shifted from Oyoroi (heavy armor) to Haramaki (a breast protection); a shallow saddle was more used than a deep one.

sen.j: 戦国時代に突入すると、騎馬武者の使用武器は同時期に発案された槍が主流となり、軍役にも装備するべき武器として記載される様になる。
sen.e: When the Sengoku period started, spears introduced around the same time became the main weapon used by mounted warriors, and also listed as must-have items for a military service.
When the Sengoku period started, spears introduced around the same time became the main weapon used by mounted warriors, and also listed as must-have items for a military service.
When the Sengoku period started, spears introduced around the same time became the main weapon used by mounted warriors, and also listed as must-have items for a military service.

sen.j: もっとも、先述した様に侍は自弁である為、軍装に関してはかなりの自由裁量が認められており、弓・鉄砲又は槍の替わりに薙刀を武家奉公人に持たす事で様々な武器を扱った。
sen.e: However, since each samurai paid his own expences during the military service as mentioned before, the war outfit was almost left to the discretion of individuals; each samurai used various arms such as a bow, a gun, a spear or even a Japanese halberd carried by Buke hokonin.

However, since each samurai paid his own expences during the military service as mentioned before, the war outfit was almost left to the discretion of individuals; each samurai used various arms such as a bow, a gun, a spear or even a Japanese halberd carried by Buke hokonin.

However, since each samurai paid his own expences during the military service as mentioned before, the war outfit was almost left to the discretion of individuals; each samurai used various arms such as a bow, a gun, a spear or even a Japanese halberd carried by Buke hokonin.

sen.j: 因みに日本刀は他の武器とは異なり、平安時代より一貫して自身が持つ武器であるが、これは身分を示すものとして佩用されるのが主な理由で、実用としては副武装の位置にある。
sen.e: In addition, unlike other arms, a Japanese sword was consistently worn in person from the Heian period mainly to show social status, regarded as a supplementary outfit for practical purposes.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: In addition, unlike other arms, a Japanese sword was consistently worn in person from the Heian period mainly to show social status, and was regarded as a supplementary outfit for practical purposes.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処はOKregardedの前にwasを追加
sen.e: In addition, unlike other arms, a Japanese sword was consistently worn in person from the Heian period mainly to show social status, and was regarded as a supplementary outfit for practical purposes.

sen.j: （刀を主要武器として使わない者が皆無であったという意味ではない。）
sen.e: (It does not mean that nobody used a Japanese sword as a main weapon.)
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: (It does not mean that nobody used a Japanese sword as a main weapon.)
(It does not mean that nobody used a Japanese sword as a main weapon.)

sen.j: 戦国時代の騎馬武者も当初は騎乗突撃をもって敵陣に突入していた様である。
sen.e: Initially, mounted warriors in the Sengoku period seemed to rush at the enemy's position by riding on horseback.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Initially, mounted warriors in the Sengoku period seemed to rush at the enemy's position by riding on horseback.
Initially, mounted warriors in the Sengoku period seemed to rush at the enemy's position by riding on horseback.

sen.j: (この時、若党は後続させていたが敵陣との距離は火縄銃の射程を考慮すれば100m以下であるので、追い付くのは容易であろう。)
sen.e: (For that occasion, young samurai, who followed close behind mounted warriors, probably caught up with them easily because the distance to the enemy was only 100 meters in consideration of shooting range of a matchlock gun.)
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: (For that occasion, young samurai, who followed close behind mounted warriors, probably caught up with them easily because the distance to the enemy was only 100 meters in consideration of shooting range of a matchlock gun.)

(For that occasion, young samurai, who followed close behind mounted warriors, probably caught up with them easily because the distance to the enemy was only 100 meters in consideration of shooting range of a matchlock gun.)

sen.j: しかし足軽の増大と彼らが繰り出す対騎馬隊戦法により、先ず西国から、後には全国的に馬から降りて徒歩で突撃する様になった。
sen.e: However, with the increase of Ashigaru and the emergence of its military strategy against cavalry, rushing at the enemy's position on foot by dismounting from the horse became common first in the western part of Japan, and later throughout the country.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: However, with the increase of ashigaru and the emergence of its military strategy against cavalry, rushing at the enemy's position on foot by dismounting from the horse became common first in the western part of Japan, and later throughout the country.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処はOKAshigaru → ashigaru
sen.e: However, with the increase of ashigaru and the emergence of its military strategy against cavalry, rushing at the enemy's position on foot by dismounting from the horse became common first in the western part of Japan, and later throughout the country.

sen.j: (騎馬武者に対する長槍による槍衾、鉄砲隊による射撃は双方とも馬を狙う事が肝要とされている)。
sen.e: (Aming at horses was considered very important in both Yaribusuma [a line of long spears held ready to attack] and shooting by musket troops against mounted warriors.)
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: (Aming at horses was considered very important in both Yaribusuma [a line of long spears held ready to attack] and shooting by musket troops against mounted warriors.)
(Aming at horses was considered very important in both Yaribusuma [a line of long spears held ready to attack] and shooting by musket troops against mounted warriors.)

sen.j: しかしそれ以前、平安時代より騎馬武者は必要があれば下馬戦闘も行ってきたし、下馬戦闘が主流になった後も機会があれば騎乗突撃を行っているなど、相手の戦法によって柔軟に運用している。
sen.e: However, back from the Heian period, mounted warriors performed land battle when necessary; after land battle became common, they fought from horseback whenever occasion arose, and responded flexibly to the enemy's strategy.

However, back from the Heian period, mounted warriors performed land battle when necessary; after land battle became common, they fought from horseback whenever occasion arose, and responded flexibly to the enemy's strategy.

However, back from the Heian period, mounted warriors performed land battle when necessary; after land battle became common, they fought from horseback whenever occasion arose, and responded flexibly to the enemy's strategy.
